close_symbols: OS_TranslatePath return-code definitions (other OS_* codes it may return)
explanation:
To decide if any part of OS_chmod is unreachable you must know whether the conditional (return_code == OS_SUCCESS) can be both true and false at compile/run time and whether the call inside it can be optimized away or made unreachable. Specifically:

- OS_TranslatePath: the implementation/signature is required to determine what return values it can produce and whether it can ever return OS_SUCCESS (or always/never do so). If it is a wrapper that always returns a constant, the branch may be unreachable.

- OS_FileChmod_Impl: the implementation/signature is required to see whether the call inside the conditional has side effects, is a no-op, marked noreturn, inlined-away, or otherwise influences reachability of the branch body.

- OS_SUCCESS: the macro/enum value used in the comparison is needed to evaluate the condition. If OS_SUCCESS has a value that makes the comparison constant under known return patterns, the branch may be unreachable.

- OS_TranslatePath return-code definitions (other OS_* codes it may return): the set of possible return codes (enums/macros) from OS_TranslatePath is required to know whether the equality test can ever be false/true; listing all possible return values is necessary for a complete reachability analysis.

- OS_MAX_LOCAL_PATH_LEN: the local array size may affect compiler optimizations (e.g. if path handling is resolved at compile time) and is part of the function’s visible state; include its definition to ensure no compile-time constant folding makes code unreachable.

- int32 and uint32 typedefs: the exact typedefs are needed to fully understand the function signature/return semantics (and any platform-specific attributes) when reasoning about constant propagation and reachability.

These symbols provide the behavioral and compile-time information required to determine whether the if-branch (and thus any code in OS_chmod) can be unreachable under the project’s definitions and build.
